article.title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation
article.abstract: Spaceflight impacts astronauts in many ways but little is known on how spaceflight affects the salivary microbiome and the consequences of these changes on astronaut health, such as viral reactivation.

sections.introduction: The World Health Organization published a surveillance strategy report in 2015 stating that worldwide, non-infectious disease (NIDs) represented 43% of global disease burden and was expected to be responsible for 60% of the disease burden and 73% of all deaths by 2020s [1].
sections.methods: Saliva samples were collected from 10 male astronauts at various time points over the course of their mission.
sections.results: Eighty-nine samples from ten astronauts were analyzed by 16S rRNA gene sequencing for microbiome analysis and qPCR for viral titer measurements.
sections.discussion: The human microbiome has become a powerful tool to help predict and modulate health and disease.

article.insights_summary: This study found that spaceflight impacts the salivary microbiome of astronauts, with changes in the composition of the microbiome potentially contributing to viral reactivation. Further studies are needed to fully understand the relationship between the microbiome and viral reactivation in astronauts.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to thank all the astronauts who participated in this study and provided saliva.
